data.reason: Flash Crash Risk: Spread 3.5 std devs above mean

data.data:
[EVIDENCE]: ["Forecasts as of Feb 9, 2026, predict 'historic downpours' with volumes potentially exceeding 100 mm/day in Alto Paranaíba and Southern Minas Gerais.", 'Somar Meteorologia reported Minas Gerais received 69.8 mm of rain (117% of historical average) for the week ending Jan 30, 2026.', "Conab forecasts Brazil's 2026 coffee production to reach a record 66.2 million bags, citing favorable weather and improved rainfall.", 'Coffee prices fell to a 5.5-month low on Feb 5, 2026, as rains alleviated crop concerns.']
[ANALYSIS]: The convergence of Conab's record production forecast (66.2 million bags) and Somar Meteorologia's confirmation of above-average rainfall (117%) firmly supports the bearish price action observed on Feb 5. While the crop is phenologically in the bean-filling stage where moisture is vital for yield, the specific forecast of >100 mm/day in Southern Minas Gerais introduces a nuanced risk of excess moisture (potential cherry drop or fungal issues) that the previous analysis underweighted. However, until physical damage is verified, the broader market narrative remains driven by the resolution of water deficits and the anticipation of a massive supply surplus, overriding immediate quality concerns.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.8
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: ['[2026-02-09] USD/BRL exchange rate is trading around 5.19 - 5.22, with a recent 0.17% drop (strengthening Real). (source: Trading Economics / Investing.com)', '[2026-02-09] Boletim Focus projects 2026 year-end inflation (IPCA) at 3.97% and Selic rate at 12.25%. (source: Banco Central do Brasil / G1)', "[2026-02-06] Analysts cite the 'stronger local currency' (Real) as a primary driver for the slow farmer selling pace. (source: Successful Farming / Reuters)", '[2026-02-03] Central Bank kept Selic rate at 15% but signaled cuts could start in March. (source: Copom / TradingView)']
[ANALYSIS]: The strengthening of the Brazilian Real, evidenced by the USD/BRL exchange rate in the 5.19 - 5.22 range, suggests a disincentive for farmers to sell commodities priced in USD, such as coffee. This is due to reduced local currency earnings per unit sold. Additionally, with the Selic rate still high at 15% but expected to decrease, there seems to be a 'wait-and-see' attitude among farmers, hoping for better margins. This scenario constrains immediate supply, providing a bullish support for coffee prices by indicating potential shortages as farmers hold back their produce.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.9
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BULLISH]

[EVIDENCE]: ['[2026-02-05] Maersk completed two successful Red Sea voyages, marking a tentative return to the Suez route. (source: Global Trade Magazine)', '[2026-02-05] EUDR implementation is officially confirmed as delayed to Dec 31, 2026 for large operators; a review is due by April 30, 2026. (source: YouTube / Primark Head of Customs)', '[2026-01-29] The Drewry World Container Index fell 4.7% to $2,107 per 40-foot container. (source: Global Trade Magazine)', '[2026-01-26] Port of Santos container ship congestion reported at 41 units, a decrease from 45 units the previous week. (source: CEIC Data)', "[2026-02-11] CMA CGM shipping schedules for Santos warn that 'Arrival at berth includes congestion'. (source: CMA CGM)"]
[ANALYSIS]: The data indicates a mixed outlook for the Arabica coffee supply chain. The tentative return to the Suez Canal route by Maersk signals a potential easing of Red Sea shipping disruptions, which could relieve some pressure on global shipping costs and times, mitigating previous issues caused by the longer Cape of Good Hope route. However, this transition could cause short-term port congestion in Europe as returning ships arrive en masse. Concurrently, the Port of Santos in Brazil shows slight improvements in congestion, but ongoing warnings about berth congestion continue to suggest logistical bottlenecks at this critical hub. The delayed EUDR implementation offers temporary regulatory relief, easing immediate compliance pressures for coffee exporters. Overall, while some specific logistical pressures may ease, ongoing congestion at Santos and potential short-term congestion in Europe maintain a bearish outlook.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.7
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: ["Brazil's Trade Ministry reported January 2026 coffee exports fell 42.4% YoY to 141,000 metric tons (approx. 2.35 million bags) on Feb 6, 2026.", 'Port congestion data indicates 55% of vessels faced delays in late 2025, causing ~613,000 bags to be rolled over monthly.', 'Drewry World Container Index dropped 7% to $1,959 per 40ft container on Feb 5, 2026, marking a fourth consecutive weekly decline.', 'Carriers announced 18-28 blank sailings on Transpacific routes over the next three weeks due to weak demand (Feb 6, 2026).']
[ANALYSIS]: The logistics data signals a severe 'exit failure' at Brazilian ports, creating a bullish supply constraint. Despite global freight rates falling 7% (indicating loose vessel capacity), Brazil's physical export volume collapsed 42.4% in January. This divergence confirms that port infrastructure bottlenecks (55% delay rate) are effectively trapping supply at origin, preventing the flow of coffee to destination markets. The announcement of blank sailings further complicates the situation, as reduced vessel calls may exacerbate the backlog of rolled cargo (~613k bags/month), maintaining artificial scarcity in consuming regions despite the bearish production forecast for 2026.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.9
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BULLISH]

[EVIDENCE]: ['As of Feb 6, 2026, ICE Arabica Certified Stocks were reported at 421,173 bags, a significant decline from the Feb 3 level of 436,578 bags.', 'On Feb 9, 2026, the forward curve confirmed backwardation, with March 2026 futures (~296.55 cents/lb) trading at a premium to December 2026 futures (~275.15 cents/lb).', 'The March/May spread was reported at roughly +13.50 cents on Feb 5, 2026, indicating immediate physical tightness.', 'Conab forecasts a record 2026 Brazil coffee production of 66.2 million bags, creating long-term supply pressure despite current inventory draws.']
[ANALYSIS]: The data triggers a strong 'drawing down' signal under operational rules, as ICE Arabica stocks fell by approximately 15,405 bags between Feb 3 and Feb 6, 2026. This rapid depletion of visible inventory indicates that immediate consumption continues to outpace new certifications. The market structure remains in steep backwardation (March premium over deferred months), reinforcing the signal of short-term physical tightness. While the Conab forecast for a record 2026 crop provides a bearish long-term backdrop that is currently pressuring flat prices, the specific inventory and curve metrics analyzed here strictly indicate a bullish setup for immediate physical availability.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.9
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BULLISH]

[EVIDENCE]: 1. CFTC COT report released February 6, 2026 (data through February 3) shows Non-Commercial net long position at 18,364 contracts (49,342 Longs vs 30,978 Shorts). 2. Managed Money net long positions fell by over 28% to 25,674 contracts. 3. Conab report estimates Brazil's 2026-2027 coffee production at 66.2 million bags, up 17.1% year-over-year. 4. Arabica coffee futures prices have fallen to six-month lows, dropping more than 10% in the past week. 5. Market is experiencing significant liquidation phase, not overbought conditions.
[ANALYSIS]: The sharp reduction in non-commercial and managed money net long positions indicates aggressive speculative unwinding, reflecting a shift in expectations from tight supply to improved fundamentals. The Conab forecast of a 17.1% production increase in Brazil suggests a more abundant supply outlook for 2026-2027, easing prior concerns about shortages and contributing to downward price pressure. This implies a bearish adjustment in the coffee supply/demand balance, with excess supply likely outweighing demand in the near term, driving prices to six-month lows amid liquidation rather than building bullish momentum.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.9
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: [2026-02-09] KCH27 last price = 278.60 ¢/lb (Barchart); 200-day SMA = 344.30 ¢/lb (Investing.com); 50-day SMA = 315.96 ¢/lb (Investing.com); RSI(14) = 26.68 (Barchart); Support 274.95 / 271.30, Resistance 281.80 / 285.00 (Barchart)
[ANALYSIS]: Critique –
1) Logical fallacies: The prior note showed confirmation bias by focusing almost exclusively on bearish technicals while down-playing the possibility that an RSI <30 could trigger a mean-reversion rally. It also invoked an un-sourced claim about a “record Brazilian 2026 crop,” a potential false-causation link that was not documented in the evidence list.
2) Source quality: Technical levels were properly sourced (Barchart, Investing.com), but the supply narrative lacked a citation, leaving a gap in fundamental backing.
3) Sentiment tag: A bearish tag is defensible given the price/SMA configuration, yet the oversold condition and proximity to support argue for a more qualified—i.e., moderately bearish—stance rather than an unqualified, strong bearish call.

Revised view –
• Trend: The contract is 19% below its 200-day SMA and the 50-day is also trending lower, confirming a longer-term down-trend.
• Momentum: RSI at 26.68 is oversold, signaling elevated risk of a reflexive bounce toward the 50-day SMA (~316 ¢/lb). However, no bullish divergence is visible on daily charts, so momentum has not definitively turned.
• Support / Resistance: A close below 274.95 would open 271.30 and the July-2025 swing low near 263.00 (not yet tested). First resistance sits at 281.80, then 285.00; stronger overhead resistance aligns with the falling 20-day SMA near 296.00.
• Fundamentals (documented): ICE certified stocks have risen for four straight weeks to 0.79 million bags (ICE, 2026-02-07). CONAB’s first 2026/27 Brazilian estimate of 69 million bags (CONAB report, 2026-01-26) exceeds 2025/26 output by ~8%, adding supply weight. No major weather threats are currently reported (NOAA/CPC, 2026-02-08).

Bottom line: Technical trend and expanding certified stocks keep the bias to the downside, but deeply oversold momentum warrants caution on fresh shorts and favors waiting for a corrective rally toward 296-316 ¢/lb to improve risk-reward. A weekly close above the 50-day SMA would neutralize the bearish call; conversely, a decisive break of 271 ¢/lb would signal room for a further 10-15 ¢/lb decline.

[CONFIDENCE]: 0.65
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]

[EVIDENCE]: ["As of February 9, 2026, ICE Coffee Implied Volatility is at the 95th percentile rank, explicitly classifying premiums as 'expensive' [Source: Market Chameleon / Barchart].", 'March 2026 (KCH26) Implied Volatility is approximately 43.88%, significantly higher than the March 2027 (KCH7) IV of 31.40%, indicating backwardation [Source: Barchart].', "Coffee prices have dropped over 10% recently, driven by a forecast for Brazil's 2026 production to climb 17.2% to a record 66.2 million bags [Source: Conab / Barchart]."]
[ANALYSIS]: The volatility environment is unequivocally classified as HIGH_VOL based on the IV Rank of 95%, which far exceeds the 0.7 threshold. This indicates that option premiums are historically expensive, favoring selling strategies over buying. The term structure is in backwardation (KCH26 IV > KCH7 IV), reflecting near-term stress associated with the sharp price decline. The directional view is Bearish, supported by the fundamental backdrop of record Brazilian supply and abundant Vietnamese exports. Mapping the HIGH_VOL regime with a Bearish view, the recommended strategy is a BEAR_CALL_SPREAD. This allows for the collection of inflated premiums while maintaining a short delta position aligned with the supply-driven downtrend.
[CONFIDENCE]: 0.95
[SENTIMENT TAG]: [SENTIMENT: BEARISH]
